Dr. Menui Will
Leave Hopkins
For Princeton

Goes To Princeton

It was at 12.20 Tuesday that a
group of bloodthirsty freshmen saw
prominent sophomore Jerry Branewer leaving Levering Hall.
"Ah," said the leader, "Here's
where we have some fun."
The frosh started running, Branower started running. Some sophomores arrived; they started running.
The 1935 , Freshman-Sophomore battle was on.

Francis White Professor Of
Greek Accepts Position In
Humanistic Studies School

Lame Here In '33

Tommy Dukehart was the first
fighter to be chilled by the icy waters
of the pond behind Levering Hall.
After the arrival of reinforcements,
the battlers were being thrown into
the water with such rapidity, that an
accurate count of the total number
was impossible.

Graduate Of Hamilton College; Once Taught Greek
At University Of Michigan
Dr. Benjamin D. Meritt, Francis
White professor of Greek at the Johns
Hopkins University, has accepted the
post of professor in the new school
of humanistic studies at Princeton
University, it was announced recently.
Dr. Meritt is one of two professors

—Courtesy Sun papers.

recently appointed to the institute for
advanced studies at Princeton. The

DR. BENJAMIN D. MERITT

other appointment went to Dr. Erwin
Panofsky, former professor of tile

McNeal Wins Prize
For Paper Read At
Engineers'Conclave

history of Art at the University of
Hamburg, Germany.
Appointed In 1933
Upon the retirement of Dr. Charles
W. E. Miller from the Johns Hopkins
University faculty in June 1933, Dr.
Meritt was chosen to take over his
duties. During the preceding twelve
months Dr. Meritt had been studying
at the American School of Classical
Studies at Athens. He came to Baltimore from Ann Arbor, Michigan,
where for a number of years he had
been professor of Geek at the Univesity of Michigan.
Dr. Meritt was graduated from the
Hamilton College, Clinton, New York
in 1920, as valedictorian of his class.
He spent the next two years studying
in Greece. In 1925 he received his
doctorate of philosophy from Princeton University, an& then returned to
Greece to spend four years in research and teaching at the American
School of Classical Studies.
Plays Flute
An excellent flutist, Dr. Meritt
spent the two years following his
graduation from Hamilton College,
wandering around Europe, playing
his flute. Funds earned as a business
manager of a campus publication at
first supported him in his travels.
These resources soon gave out, and
he found himself in Greece with nothing but a desire to see what was in
the land of the ancients.
Returning from Athens, Dr. Meritt
joined the faculty of the University
of Vermont in 1923.
Famous Greek Scholar
Dr. Tenney Frank, professor of
Latin at the Johns Hopkins has said
of Dr. Meritt, "for a man of his
age, he is probably the best known
scholar along Greek lines in America
today." He won his reputation, according to Dr. Frank, "largely by
working over revision of the Acropolis inscriptions and by his work on
the inscriptions found in the American
School of Classical Studies excavations at Corinth.
In the past, Dr. Meritt has played
tennis and collected stamps. He is
thirty-six years old, married, a native of North Carolina, and he enjoys
academic controversies — especially
When the gentleman of the other part
doesn't understand calculus. Dr. Meritt does.

Dr. Finney Presides
At Faculty Meeting
Dr. J. M. T. Finney, professor emeritus of surgery at the Johns Hopkins,
Presided at the meeting where several
hundred physicians and surgeons from
In parts of Maryland Tuesday night
heard Dr. Leonard G. Rowntree, of
iadelphia, lecture on thymus and
Pineal gland extract experiments. The
lecture was given at the Medical and
r-'
,hirurgical Faculty Building, 1211
Cathedral street.
This talk was part of the faculty's
Innual meeting, which began Mon:lay and ended with a buffet supper
St the Cathedral street building Tueslay night. The Philadelphian deScribed rapid physical and sexual development obtained in rats by the injection of thymus gland extract and
dwarfism obtained in the rodents by
pineal gland extract.

Frosh-Soph Battles Open
Early On Varied Fronts

Sonic Depth Finding Subject
Of Talk; Hopkins Student
Received Award Last Year
James W. McNeal, a senior engineer
at the Hopkins, was awarded first
prize of ten dollars for a paper read
at the Eleventh Student Branch of
the American Institute of Electrical

However, Tuesday's war was not
the first meeting between the class
of '37 and the class of '38. On Monday evening, the members• of the
classes, living in the dorms, indulged
in a gentle bit of horse play.
The freshmen had organized a sieging party, but the sophs could turn
only toward locking themselves in
their rooms for protection from the
savage 1938 model barbarians.
Even that did not stop the eager
first year men. Several of them had
gained entrance to the individual
rooms via the roof and windows.
The punishment meted out to the
poor sophs was severe indeed. Their
locks were shorn. Their faces were
painted. They were thrown into the
pond.
After a brief stay at the pond, both
classes returned to the dorms, where
most of the activities took place at
A entry.
One sophomore had safely locked
himself in his room, but discovering
that his room-mate was still out in

the midst of the horrible fighting, set
out to rescue him. Result: One wellmeaning sophomore thrown into the
pond.
The evening battle was finally ended when John Stevens, a soph turned
a high-pressure fire extinguisher on
the host of invading freshmen and
caused them to return to their beds.
During another escapade, the
freshmen managed to capture Brian
Murphy, chairman of the Sophomore
Banquet Committee. With Murphy
went all plans for a Sophomore Banquet. Have no fear, sophomores, for
Murphy made his escape yesterday
afternoon. Grove, sophomore president, had been captured, too, but he
also is free now.
Meanwhile Thomas Ellis, freshman
president, is taking all precautions
and has moved out of the dorms, in
order to prevent his inevitable kidnapping. Romanofsky, Pinkerton, and
Royster, Freshman Class officers,
have taken residence in one of the
hotels until after the Freshman Banquet.
A group of marauding freshmen on
the alert for sophs, managed to capture Henry Kramer, and after giving
him a haircut, persuaded him that he
had need of a bath. Hence a ducking
in the frog pond back of Levering
Hall. At about 11 p. m. William
O'Brien was treated to a slight haircut and kidnapped at 1 a. m. yesterday. At 11.30, Red Alexander and M.
Tuerk were taken in E Entry, and
marched out to the frog pond. After
being painted up with mercurochrome, and massaged with raw eggs,
they were treated to a ducking.
The next scene of disturbance was
in A entry where one of the huge
fire extinguishers was used to hold
several freshmen at bay.

Dr. George M. A. Hanfmann of
the Hopkins has been appointed to
the Society of Fellows at Harvard
University, it was announced at
the beginning of the week by the
college authorities at Harvard.
The appointment provides the
recipient with an opportunity for
three years of independent study
and research at Harvard with an
annual stipend of $1,250. There
were five appointments to the
group, according to a dispatch
from Harvard.
Dr. Hanfmann received his Ph.D.
degree in Etruscan archaeology at
the University of Berlin. He was
given the grade of summa cum
laude for the oral examination by
the Judges at Harvard, while the
thesis was judged an opus eximium. The thesis dealt with the beginnings of Etruscan art.
He will continue his work in
Etruscan art at the Hopkins.

When Governor Nice says to exGovernor Ritchie, "the planks are
missing from the back stairs of the
executive mansion. Do you know
where they are?" And ex-Governor
Ritchie answers, "Yes, I used them in
my platform," we have a few typical
lines from the Charles Street Follies,
now being presented at the Guild Theatre.
The whole production is of the tune
indicated above—and at times, often,
in fact—a great deal spicier.
There is little doubt that this edition of the Follies far surpasses any
preceding ones. Not only is the audience imbued with a joyful attitude,
but the cast itself is so engrossed in
its presentation, that the icleverly
written skits and songs are still more
cleverly executed.
Opening with a burlesque on a
CCC Works Project, the audience
finds the laborers hard at work for
the government, playing ping-pong,
and complaining of the long hours of
strenuous work which they must put
in. Immediately following is a pleasant interlude of tap dancing, and then
we find ourselves in the Governor's
mansion. The Governor and Mrs. Nice
are entertaining ex-Governor Ritchie,
and girl friend. And so runs the
whole play, packed with wit, songs,
and lively dances.
The best scene of the show has as
locale a graveyard, with Gertrude
Stein reciting her poetry over the
grave of Edgar Allen Poe. Awakened
by the noise, Poe demands to know
what Miss Stein is saying, and they
get to quareling, when in walks Syd-

ney Lanier. To make a foursome,
Ogden Nash enters and the ensuing
dialogue has to be heard to be enjoyed.
A close runner-up for first honors,
is the scene which is evidently in the
Oriole Restaurant. A song depicting
the hardships of the traybearer,
coupled with clever acting, and the
insistent demand of "I want ice
cream," made by the girl with the
long hair, produce the most humorous and witty scenes I've witnessed in
a long time.
Among other scenes are portrayals
of Washington at "Valley George,"
"Quest for Literature," which is a
burlesque of an hour at Pratt Library,
and a "Directors' Conference" which
should quicken the pulses and hearts
of many a Hopkins student. Why?
Well, go see for yourself.
Pleasant interludes are provided
between scenes when Mr. Stagestruck Cushing faces the audience
and exhibits pictures of a lake upside
down accompanied by incoherent humorous pearls of wisdom.
There are several beautiful-anddiverting (catch?)—dance numbers,
which must be seen to be enjoyed.
One number in particular—"Red
Lights"—is done on an asbestos floor
to prevent combustion.
Carroll Robinson and Edmund
Leonard take leading male parts
with the Misses Greene occupying the
same position in regard to female
roles. Dance numbers by Miss Poska
are worth attention, as is the singing
of Miss Kay Lewis.
—JACK STEIN.

He kicked the lad three blocks away

Dr. William Kelso Morrill has ordered his lacrosse players to abstain
from all indulgence in Hell Week.
Before the order was given, several
members of the squad had been halfstripped and all wet in celebration
of the week.
The report is, on the authority of
Johnny Himes—who made it up—
that anybody enticing a member of
the lacrosse team into Hell Week
activity will bust his math course.

Next Attraction

While Mt. Washington has the better record this year, it is to be remembered that the figures don't tell
the whole story.
The Morrillmen
have been coming along fast as they
gained experience, and figure to
complete their season with only one
defeat—the one provided by B. A. C.
The Jays' speed, stamina, and reserve power is counted upon to carry
the ten safely past Mt. Washington.

Johns Hopkins Handball Team will

courts late this afternoon. A return
match will be played with this 'University's handball squad tomorrow

consist of four singles and two doubles. The following Tuesday afternoon the team will meet the St.

History was in the making in the
intramural athletic department last
Sunday, when Reuben Baer pitched
the Graduate Student softball team
to victory over the Dormitory team,
by means of a no-hit, no-run game.
The score was 7 to 0.
It seems that there was a sort of
feud between the boys from the dormitory and Mr. Baer. Consequently
the failure of the losers to hit Mr.
Baer's brilliant pitching was a keen
disappointment.
The Dormitory team turned the
tables in the next game, winning by
a score of 9-2.

Our present-day economic life is
based upon a false economic plan.
That is, namely, that the issue of
money must be controlled by private
individuals, they to be allowed the
power to set up a standard of value
contrary to the constitution of the
United States, which says that Congress must issue the money and create the value thereof, and of foreign
coins, and establish a uniform standard of weights and measures.
Our present banking and credit
currency system, owned and controlled by the international bankers, has
given to the people of the United
States a Federal Reserve Bank System which they own and by using a
3 per cent cash basis they have circulated 97 per cent bank credit, represented by check money, being a
counterfeit and substitute for lawful
money and based on this foreign
scheme, and engineered through legislation instituted, guided, and manipulated by Wall Street bankers, and
contrary to the Constitution of the
United States.
Today we find the American people
living in a debtors' prison, enslaved
to the shackles of credit, and until
these shackles are removed from
American industry and agriculture
there can never be a settlement of
the unemployment question, which
dominates and robs the peoples of
America of their economic rights to
live.
The climax of this national crisis is
close at hand. Its present phases are
economic depressions, unemployment,
starvation, foreclosures and dispossession, bankruptcies of individuals,
firms, corporations, cities, states and
nations. Lawlessness and disorder
continue throughout the land.
Neither the Republican or Democratic Party, nor Franklin Delano
Roosevelt, President of the United
States, offer any plan or remedy of
the situation in the economic field.
Bankers and men have made gold
their God and with millions of dollars
in gold locked up in the United States
Treasury, used as a basis of debt to
further enslave the people, the Golden God has forsaken them because it
is a delusion. It's a snare through
which the net of the international
bankers has drawn all men and nations into its coils. It offers no hope
because its plan is to further the
people in debt--a debt which can
never be paid with the gold in their
possession. Its chains are already
strangling the race physically and
spiritually into submission through
starvation and misery resulting from
plans to accomplish world financial
rulership and ownership of mankind
on earth as economic slaves.

Supper Club Announcement
Born in London in 1873, Harry F.
Ward came to America at the age
of 18. After taking his A. B. degree
at Northwestern University and A.
M. at Harvard, he entered the ministry, where he was very active in the
field of social serice. In 1907 he
founded the Methodist Federation of
Social Service, and for many years
has served as general secretary of
that organization. Since 1918 he has
been professor of Christian Ethics at
Union Theological Seminary, New
York. He is the author of more than
a dozen books dealing mainly with
the social and economic implications
of religion, among which are: "The
Profit Motive," "Our Economic Morality," "Which Way Religion?" and
"In Place of Profit."

The Farmer-Labor Party endeavors
to meet this economic principle and
political issue in that battle of ballots which in 1936 will make money
and credit the servant and not the
master of mankind.
Capitalism faces a crisis—whether
or not this is to be the final crisis depends upon whether or not its palsied
control of power is resolutely challenged. Capitalism will not be destroyed merely by wishing for its end.
Regardless of its mistakes, injustices,
weaknesses, capitalism will cease to
exist only when the workers of hand
and brain, from the schools and colleges, from the farms and the factories, and the offices, recognize their
common interest and unite and seize
power to hold it.
Production for profit, with its concomitant elements of greed, exploitation and cut-throat competition is the
cornerstone of the capitalistic arch.
That is why the problem of distribution under mass production can never
be solved with equity and justice by
a capitalistic controlled society. That
is why capitalism must be destroyed;
that is why it must be inevitably superceded by some form of a coopera-

It was at 12.20 Tuesday that a
group of bloodthirsty freshmen saw
prominent sophomore Jerry Branewer leaving Levering Hall.
"Ah," said the leader, "Here's
where we have some fun."
The frosh started running, Branower started running. Some sophomores arrived; they started running.
The 1935 , Freshman-Sophomore battle was on.

of the pond behind Levering Hall.
After the arrival of reinforcements,
the battlers were being thrown into

was impossible.

Graduate Of Hamilton College; Once Taught Greek
At University Of Michigan
Dr. Benjamin D. Meritt, Francis
White professor of Greek at the Johns
Hopkins University, has accepted the
post of professor in the new school
of humanistic studies at Princeton
University, it was announced recently.
Dr. Meritt is one of two professors

Appointed In 1933
Upon the retirement of Dr. Charles
W. E. Miller from the Johns Hopkins
University faculty in June 1933, Dr.
Meritt was chosen to take over his
duties. During the preceding twelve
months Dr. Meritt had been studying
at the American School of Classical
Studies at Athens. He came to Baltimore from Ann Arbor, Michigan,
where for a number of years he had
been professor of Geek at the Univesity of Michigan.
Dr. Meritt was graduated from the
Hamilton College, Clinton, New York
in 1920, as valedictorian of his class.
He spent the next two years studying
in Greece. In 1925 he received his
doctorate of philosophy from Princeton University, an& then returned to
Greece to spend four years in research and teaching at the American
School of Classical Studies.
Plays Flute
An excellent flutist, Dr. Meritt
spent the two years following his
graduation from Hamilton College,
wandering around Europe, playing
his flute. Funds earned as a business
manager of a campus publication at
first supported him in his travels.
These resources soon gave out, and
he found himself in Greece with nothing but a desire to see what was in
the land of the ancients.
Returning from Athens, Dr. Meritt
joined the faculty of the University
of Vermont in 1923.
Famous Greek Scholar
Dr. Tenney Frank, professor of
Latin at the Johns Hopkins has said
of Dr. Meritt, "for a man of his
age, he is probably the best known
scholar along Greek lines in America
today." He won his reputation, according to Dr. Frank, "largely by
working over revision of the Acropolis inscriptions and by his work on
the inscriptions found in the American
School of Classical Studies excavations at Corinth.
In the past, Dr. Meritt has played
tennis and collected stamps. He is
thirty-six years old, married, a native of North Carolina, and he enjoys
academic controversies — especially
When the gentleman of the other part
doesn't understand calculus. Dr. Meritt does.

However, Tuesday's war was not
the first meeting between the class
of '37 and the class of '38. On Monday evening, the members• of the
classes, living in the dorms, indulged
in a gentle bit of horse play.
The freshmen had organized a sieging party, but the sophs could turn
only toward locking themselves in
their rooms for protection from the
savage 1938 model barbarians.
Even that did not stop the eager
first year men. Several of them had
gained entrance to the individual
rooms via the roof and windows.
The punishment meted out to the
poor sophs was severe indeed. Their
locks were shorn. Their faces were
painted. They were thrown into the
pond.
After a brief stay at the pond, both
classes returned to the dorms, where
most of the activities took place at
A entry.
One sophomore had safely locked
himself in his room, but discovering
that his room-mate was still out in

the midst of the horrible fighting, set
out to rescue him. Result: One wellmeaning sophomore thrown into the
pond.
The evening battle was finally ended when John Stevens, a soph turned
a high-pressure fire extinguisher on
the host of invading freshmen and
caused them to return to their beds.
During another escapade, the
freshmen managed to capture Brian
Murphy, chairman of the Sophomore
Banquet Committee. With Murphy
went all plans for a Sophomore Banquet. Have no fear, sophomores, for
Murphy made his escape yesterday
afternoon. Grove, sophomore president, had been captured, too, but he
also is free now.
Meanwhile Thomas Ellis, freshman
president, is taking all precautions
and has moved out of the dorms, in
order to prevent his inevitable kidnapping. Romanofsky, Pinkerton, and
Royster, Freshman Class officers,
have taken residence in one of the
hotels until after the Freshman Banquet.
A group of marauding freshmen on
the alert for sophs, managed to capture Henry Kramer, and after giving
him a haircut, persuaded him that he
had need of a bath. Hence a ducking
in the frog pond back of Levering
Hall. At about 11 p. m. William
O'Brien was treated to a slight haircut and kidnapped at 1 a. m. yesterday. At 11.30, Red Alexander and M.
Tuerk were taken in E Entry, and
marched out to the frog pond. After
being painted up with mercurochrome, and massaged with raw eggs,
they were treated to a ducking.
The next scene of disturbance was
in A entry where one of the huge
fire extinguishers was used to hold
several freshmen at bay.

Dr. George M. A. Hanfmann of
the Hopkins has been appointed to
the Society of Fellows at Harvard
University, it was announced at
the beginning of the week by the
college authorities at Harvard.
The appointment provides the
recipient with an opportunity for
three years of independent study
and research at Harvard with an
annual stipend of $1,250. There
were five appointments to the
group, according to a dispatch
from Harvard.
Dr. Hanfmann received his Ph.D.
degree in Etruscan archaeology at
the University of Berlin. He was
given the grade of summa cum
laude for the oral examination by
the Judges at Harvard, while the
thesis was judged an opus eximium. The thesis dealt with the beginnings of Etruscan art.
He will continue his work in
Etruscan art at the Hopkins.

When Governor Nice says to exGovernor Ritchie, "the planks are
missing from the back stairs of the
executive mansion. Do you know
where they are?" And ex-Governor
Ritchie answers, "Yes, I used them in
my platform," we have a few typical
lines from the Charles Street Follies,
now being presented at the Guild Theatre.
The whole production is of the tune
indicated above—and at times, often,
in fact—a great deal spicier.
There is little doubt that this edition of the Follies far surpasses any
preceding ones. Not only is the audience imbued with a joyful attitude,
but the cast itself is so engrossed in
its presentation, that the icleverly
written skits and songs are still more
cleverly executed.
Opening with a burlesque on a
CCC Works Project, the audience
finds the laborers hard at work for
the government, playing ping-pong,
and complaining of the long hours of
strenuous work which they must put
in. Immediately following is a pleasant interlude of tap dancing, and then
we find ourselves in the Governor's
mansion. The Governor and Mrs. Nice
are entertaining ex-Governor Ritchie,
and girl friend. And so runs the
whole play, packed with wit, songs,
and lively dances.
The best scene of the show has as
locale a graveyard, with Gertrude
Stein reciting her poetry over the
grave of Edgar Allen Poe. Awakened
by the noise, Poe demands to know
what Miss Stein is saying, and they
get to quareling, when in walks Syd-

ney Lanier. To make a foursome,
Ogden Nash enters and the ensuing
dialogue has to be heard to be enjoyed.
A close runner-up for first honors,
is the scene which is evidently in the
Oriole Restaurant. A song depicting
the hardships of the traybearer,
coupled with clever acting, and the
insistent demand of "I want ice
cream," made by the girl with the
long hair, produce the most humorous and witty scenes I've witnessed in
a long time.
Among other scenes are portrayals
of Washington at "Valley George,"
"Quest for Literature," which is a
burlesque of an hour at Pratt Library,
and a "Directors' Conference" which
should quicken the pulses and hearts
of many a Hopkins student. Why?
Well, go see for yourself.
Pleasant interludes are provided
between scenes when Mr. Stagestruck Cushing faces the audience
and exhibits pictures of a lake upside
down accompanied by incoherent humorous pearls of wisdom.
There are several beautiful-anddiverting (catch?)—dance numbers,
which must be seen to be enjoyed.
One number in particular—"Red
Lights"—is done on an asbestos floor
to prevent combustion.
Carroll Robinson and Edmund
Leonard take leading male parts
with the Misses Greene occupying the
same position in regard to female
roles. Dance numbers by Miss Poska
are worth attention, as is the singing
of Miss Kay Lewis.
—JACK STEIN.

A girl friend recommended Rice

girl friend, who desired to see me a
great big he-man brought about the
switch of diet.

The men cheered, threw their hats

with the enthusiastic reception of his

"Men," he said, clearing his throat,
"I thank you."

She sweetly gave his kisses back and
said,
"Now that's subtraction."
But Dad appeared upon the scene
And made a quick decision,
He kicked the lad three blocks away
and said,
"Now that's division."

disappointment.
The Dormitory team turned the
tables in the next game, winning by
a score of 9-2.

Our present-day economic life is
based upon a false economic plan.
That is, namely, that the issue of
money must be controlled by private
individuals, they to be allowed the
power to set up a standard of value
contrary to the constitution of the
United States, which says that Congress must issue the money and create the value thereof, and of foreign
coins, and establish a uniform standard of weights and measures.
Our present banking and credit
currency system, owned and controlled by the international bankers, has
given to the people of the United
States a Federal Reserve Bank System which they own and by using a
3 per cent cash basis they have circulated 97 per cent bank credit, represented by check money, being a
counterfeit and substitute for lawful
money and based on this foreign
scheme, and engineered through legislation instituted, guided, and manipulated by Wall Street bankers, and
contrary to the Constitution of the
United States.
Today we find the American people
living in a debtors' prison, enslaved
to the shackles of credit, and until
these shackles are removed from
American industry and agriculture
there can never be a settlement of
the unemployment question, which
dominates and robs the peoples of
America of their economic rights to
live.
The climax of this national crisis is
close at hand. Its present phases are
economic depressions, unemployment,
starvation, foreclosures and dispossession, bankruptcies of individuals,
firms, corporations, cities, states and
nations. Lawlessness and disorder
continue throughout the land.
Neither the Republican or Democratic Party, nor Franklin Delano
Roosevelt, President of the United
States, offer any plan or remedy of
the situation in the economic field.
Bankers and men have made gold
their God and with millions of dollars
in gold locked up in the United States
Treasury, used as a basis of debt to
further enslave the people, the Golden God has forsaken them because it
is a delusion. It's a snare through
which the net of the international
bankers has drawn all men and nations into its coils. It offers no hope
because its plan is to further the
people in debt--a debt which can
never be paid with the gold in their
possession. Its chains are already
strangling the race physically and
spiritually into submission through
starvation and misery resulting from
plans to accomplish world financial
rulership and ownership of mankind
on earth as economic slaves.

Supper Club Announcement
Born in London in 1873, Harry F.
Ward came to America at the age
of 18. After taking his A. B. degree
at Northwestern University and A.
M. at Harvard, he entered the ministry, where he was very active in the
field of social serice. In 1907 he
founded the Methodist Federation of
Social Service, and for many years
has served as general secretary of
that organization. Since 1918 he has
been professor of Christian Ethics at
Union Theological Seminary, New
York. He is the author of more than
a dozen books dealing mainly with
the social and economic implications
of religion, among which are: "The
Profit Motive," "Our Economic Morality," "Which Way Religion?" and
"In Place of Profit."

The Farmer-Labor Party endeavors
to meet this economic principle and
political issue in that battle of ballots which in 1936 will make money
and credit the servant and not the
master of mankind.
Capitalism faces a crisis—whether
or not this is to be the final crisis depends upon whether or not its palsied
control of power is resolutely challenged. Capitalism will not be destroyed merely by wishing for its end.
Regardless of its mistakes, injustices,
weaknesses, capitalism will cease to
exist only when the workers of hand
and brain, from the schools and colleges, from the farms and the factories, and the offices, recognize their
common interest and unite and seize
power to hold it.
Production for profit, with its concomitant elements of greed, exploitation and cut-throat competition is the
cornerstone of the capitalistic arch.
That is why the problem of distribution under mass production can never
be solved with equity and justice by
a capitalistic controlled society. That
is why capitalism must be destroyed;
that is why it must be inevitably superceded by some form of a coopera-
